dc:description:
The *DRC1* (*Dynein Regulatory Complex Subunit 1*) gene, also known as *CCDC164*, was first reported in relation to PCD patients by Wirschell et al in 2013 (PMID: 23354437). Earlier work by Carlén et al. in 2003 (PMID: 12746204) had described three PCD patients with shared ultrastructural defects in their ciliary axonemes: an absence of the nexin links that connect the nine outer microtubule doublets of the ciliary and flagellar axonemes. Wirschell et al. elaborated on this PCD study by showing that loss-of-function variants disrupting *DRC1* in human patients resulted in severe defects in the assembly of what is now referred to as the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (N-DRC), a key regulator of ciliary and flagellar motor activity. In addition to bridging neighboring doublet microtubules, the N-DRC restricts their sliding motions, converting dynein-generated sliding motion into ciliary bending motion (PMID: 3771483). The DRC1 protein is one of 12 subunits of the N-DRC (PMID: 37714832). DRC1, DRC2 (CCDC65), and DRC4 (GAS8) are considered scaffold proteins of the N-DRC and play a vital role in assembling the N-DRC. Defects in each of these subunits have been associated with PCD (PMIDs: 23354437, 24094744, 26387594).

The specific disease entity associated with *DRC1* is primary ciliary dyskinesia 21, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous variants in the *DRC1* gene. Individuals with PCD due to *DRC1* variants present with upper and lower respiratory infection, infertility, and consistently demonstrate low levels of nasal nitric oxide. They do not exhibit situs inversus, a hallmark of many forms of PCD. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping & Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases caused by inherited *DRC1* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 21 (MONDO:0014123, OMIM # 615294).

The mechanism of pathogenicity in primary ciliary dyskinesia 21 appears to be biallelic *DRC1* loss of function. This curation has evaluated genetic evidence from ten probands reported in seven publications (PMIDs: 23354437, 36856967, 34089056, 32108610, 35873463, 31270959, 34815526). Six unique variants were scored from nine probands (four nonsense, one large 27,748 bp deletion spanning exons 1-4, and one 6,119 bp deletion spanning exon 2 that results in a frameshift mutation). Of note: The *DRC1* exon 1–4 deletion (NC_000002.12:g.26398040_26425787del) is a founder variant that causes PCD in Korean and Japanese populations (PMID: 39152285) and is the most prevalent variant in Japanese PCD patients (PMID: 36864285). The *DRC1* p.Gln118Ter variant (NM_145038.5:c.352C>T) was reported in five different probands, although it has not yet been identified as a founder mutation (PMIDs: 34089056, 36856967, 23354437, 34851034). Two publications report human patients with biallelic *DRC1* variants with male infertility and no respiratory symptoms (PMIDs: 39780445, 34169321). It remains unclear whether mild respiratory phenotypes were overlooked or misinterpreted as normal as these studies did not incorporate comprehensive pulmonary assessments or investigate respiratory ciliary structure or function in these patients. These patients were not scored in this curation.

The gene-disease association between *DRC1* and PCD 21 is also supported by gene expression data that show *DRC1* expression in ciliated tissues. GTEx RNA-seq expression studies in reference human tissues show strong expression of *DRC1* in lung, testis, brain, and fallopian tube (PMID: 23715323). This pattern is consistent with DRC1 as a subunit of the N-DRC in motile cilia and flagella (sperm). DRC1 together with DRC2 (CCDC65), and DRC4 (GAS8) are considered scaffold proteins in the assembly of the N-DRC. Cryo–electron tomography and structural labeling studies were used to characterize the elongated configuration of these proteins and their role as the backbone of the N-DRC (PMID: 25411337). Velocity sedimentation of NaI extracts from wild-type versus mutant *Chlamydomonas* axonemes on sucrose density gradients show that extracts derived from axonemes mutant for either *drc1* or *drc4* have a disrupted N-DRC structure with drc1 and drc4 sedimenting separately at different rates while wild-type extracts have drc1 and drc4 sedimenting together as one large complex (PMID: 23354437). Coimmunoprecipitation studies in human HEK293 cells confirm an interaction between DRC1 and DRC2 as well as DRC1 and DRC4 (PMID: 34169321). 
 
Two non-human experimental models have been used to support the gene-disease relationship between *DRC1* and PCD 21.  *Chlamydomonas* cells with loss-of-function *drc1* mutations exhibit abnormal ciliary motility and have an absence of or defective N-DRC assembly (PMID:23354437). In *Chlamydomonas*, the absence of drc1 results in reduced swimming speed, while in humans, respiratory epithelial cells show signs of impaired ciliary movement (reduced bending capacity, altered ciliary beat frequency), and likely mucociliary clearance (upper and lower respiratory symptoms). Mice carrying loss-of-function *Drc1* mutations were created with two different genetic backgrounds. *Drc1* mutant mice in the highly inbred C57BL/6 line exhibited clear signs of growth retardation and hydrocephalus and died before puberty.  Hydrocephalus is a common finding in mouse PCD models, occurring due to the defective function of motile cilia lining the ventricles of the brain. *Drc1* mutations in a hybrid C57BL/6 x ICR line allowed for some mice to reach adulthood for further phenotyping. Mice that survived to adulthood did not exhibit hydrocephalus or decreased size and show signs of male infertility due to severe sperm tail defects (PMID:34169321). In addition to sperm with abnormal morphology, both human patients and mutant mice have defective respiratory cilia, lacking the N-DRC and exhibiting altered ciliary motility.
 
In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *DRC1* and primary ciliary dyskinesia 21. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on March 13th, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored because a Chlamydomonas model is unable to recapitulate the respiratory and infertility phenotypes seen in humans with DCR1-related PCD.

Both human and Chlamydomonas cells with loss-of-function DRC1 mutations exhibit abnormal ciliary motility and have an absence of or defective N-DRC assembly.  In Chlamydomonas, the absence of DRC1 results in reduced swimming speed, while in humans, respiratory epithelial cells show signs of impaired ciliary movement (reduced bending capacity, altered ciliary beat frequency), and likely mucociliary clearance (upper and lower respiratory symptoms).
evidence.rdfs:label: Chlamydomonas drc1 mutant

evidence.dc:description: Both human patients and mice carrying loss-of-function DRC1 mutations show signs of male infertility due to severe sperm tail defects. In addition to sperm with abnormal morphology, both human patients and mutant mice have defective respiratory cilia, lacking the N-DRC and exhibiting altered ciliary motility.
evidence.rdfs:label: DRC1 loss-of function mouse model

evidence.dc:description: This study localized DRC1, DRC2, and DRC4 (N-DRC subunits) using cryo–electron tomography and structural labeling.  All three of these subunits were found to have almost the same elongated configuration in the N-DRC.  Authors note that the configuration of DRC1, DRC2, and DRC4 suggests that the three proteins serve as the backbone of the N-DRC.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cryoelectron tomograph & structural labeling of NDRC subunit

evidence.dc:description: GAS8 (DRC4) and DRC1 are both subunits of the N-DRC.  These studies also showed co-immunoprecipitation of DRC1 with CCDC65( DRC2), LRRC48(DRC3) and RSPH9. CCDC65 and GAS8 have both been implicated in human PCD (PMIDs: 24094744, 26387594, 37714832).
evidence.rdfs:label: Immuniprecipitation studies of N-DRC subunits

evidence.dc:description:
DRC1 and GAS8 (DRC4) are 2 of 12 subunits of the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (N-DRC) of the ciliary axoneme. The N-DRC plays a critical role in regulating dynein motors and connects the outer doublets to each other. Velocity sedimentation of NaI extracts from wild-type
Chlamydomonas axonemes on sucrose density gradients shows that the N-DRC (DRC1 and DRC4) sediments as a very large complex (>19S). Extracts derived from axonemes mutant for either drc1 (pf3) or drc4/gas8 (pf2) have a disrupted N-DRC structure such that DRC1 sediments at ~19S in pf2, and DRC4 sediments at ~2S in pf3.
evidence.rdfs:label: Velocity sedimentation of NaI extracts: wt, drc1, gas8 cells

evidence.dc:description: The Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project has established a resource database and associated tissue bank for the scientific community to study the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression in human tissues. RNA-seq expression studies were performed on 54 reference tissues. Bulk tissue gene expression for DRC1 shows the expression of DRC1 in lung, testis, brain, and Fallopian tube. This pattern is consistent with the presence of the N-DRC complex (of which DRC1 is one subunit) in motile cilia and sperm flagella.
evidence.rdfs:label: GTEx DRC1 gene expression
Family OP-26

member.rdfs:label: OP26 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Whole genome scan using SNP arrays and linkage analysis on family OP-26 identified candidate gene CCDC164 (DRC1). Haplotype analy­sis was consistent with homozygosity by descent. Amplification and sequencing of CCDC164 exons identi­fied a homozygous nonsense mutation.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Bronchiectasis, particularly of the middle lobe, together with mucous plugging; Respiratory cilia have a characteristic 9+2 arrangement of ciliary microtubules, along with axonemal structures, such as the radial spokes, dynein arms. Some unspe­cific ultrastructural alterations, including substitution of peripheral doublets by single tubules or the presence of supernummary single tubules.  Upon careful analysis of cross sections, authors note absence of N­-DRC link. Immunofluorescence studies with DNAH5 and DNALI1 antibodies confirm normal outer and inner dynein arms.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bronchiectasis, particularly of the middle lobe, together with mucous plugging; Respiratory cilia have a characteristic 9+2 arrangement of ciliary microtubules, along with axonemal structures, such as the radial spokes, dynein arms. Some unspe­cific ultrastructural alterations, including substitution of peripheral doublets by single tubules or the presence of supernummary single tubules.  Upon careful analysis of cross sections, authors note absence of N­-DRC link. Immunofluorescence studies with DNAH5 and DNALI1 antibodies confirm normal outer and inner dynein arms.

member.rdfs:label: OP39 II-1
member.detectionMethod: Analyzed 20 unrelated families with PCD with defects involving the N-DRC for the presence of mutations in the CCDC164 gene.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pereira Family

member.rdfs:label: Pereira II-2
member.phenotypeFreeText: Symptoms present since infancy. TEM shows absence of N-DRC in nasal cilia. HSVM shows dyskinetic ciliary beat pattern and reduced beat frequency in nasal cilia.
member.previousTestingDescription: Genotyping of the complete CFTR gene for cystic fibrosis (sequencing of all CFTR exonic regions and exon-intron junctions), which identified a heterozygous pathogenic variant in exon 16, c.617T>G, P.Leuc206Trp.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Symptoms present since infancy. TEM shows absence of N-DRC in nasal cilia. HSVM shows dyskinetic ciliary beat pattern in nasal cilia

evidence.rdfs:label: Family OP-59

member.rdfs:label: OP59 II-2
member.detectionMethod: Analyzed 20 unrelated families with PCD with defects involving the N-DRC for the presence of mutations in the CCDC164 gene.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Normal 9+2 ciliary microtubule organization with absent N-DRC links in OP-59 II-2 respiratory cells (TEM).  IF studies of respiratory cells show absence of LRRC48 (DRC3 marker for N-DRC).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal 9+2 ciliary microtubule organization with absent N-DRC links in OP-59 II-2 respiratory cells (TEM).  IF studies of respiratory cells show absence of LRRC48 (DRC3 marker for N-DRC).

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored to 1 for homozygosity (likely consanguinity)

NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.2056A>T (p.Lys686Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 7% truncated protein. DRC1 mutations result in defective N-DRC assembly in respiratory cilia. IF shows DRC proteins GAS11 (GAS8 or DRC4) and LRRC48 (DRC3) were either absent or were present at severely reduced levels relative to control axonemes in ciliary axonemes. Respiratory cilia from OP­26 II-1 showed an increased beat frequency (8–12 Hz at room temperature versus 4–8 Hz for controls). Cilia show the characteristic decreased amplitude of bending associated with defects in the N­-DRC.
Down-scored for homozygosity
NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.1205G>A (p.Trp402Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 46% truncated protein.

evidence.rdfs:label: Benjamin Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Recurrent respiratory infections with wheeze since infancy; centrilobular opacities; High-speed video microscopy analysis (HSVA) of nasal brushings revealed motile cilia with stiff motility (reducing bending capacity) and a ciliary beat frequency of 14 Hz.

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored to 1.5 for homozygosity.

NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.352C>T (p.Gln118Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 84% truncated protein. RNA expression studies (qPCR  and protein expression studies (Immunofluorescence studies with DRC1 antibody) show a reduction in mRNA and protein expression.
Down-scored to 1.5 for homozygosity.

NC_000002.12:g.26412620_26418738del is a large 6,119 bp deletion spanning exon 2 that results in a frameshift mutation (p.Glu53Asnfs*13). RT-PCR and sequencing data, validated the homozygous absence of DRC1 exon 2 at the RNA level.  Immunofluorescence analysis confirmed the absence of DRC4 (GAS8) protein expression in the ciliated tissue (respiratory ciliated cells and sperm flagellum) of the patient compared with the healthy control suggesting disruption of the N-DRC.

evidence.rdfs:label: Liu Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: WES-based SNV and INDEL analysis, followed by WES-based CNV analysis. CNV analysis returned a homozygous deletion in exon 2 of DRC1 in this patient. Further PCR amplification and Sanger sequencing validated the homozygous absence of DRC1 exon 2 at RNA level. Targeted Sanger sequencing verified the breakpoint of the DRC1 variant at the DNA level (homozygous deletion of 6119 bp).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal ciliary beating frequency and a reduced amplitude in ciliary beating pattern; MMAF phenotype; respiratory symptoms since early childhood

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored by 0.5 for homozygosity by consanguinity
NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.1296G>A (p.Trp432Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 42% truncated protein.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lei Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: MMAF; Repeated upper and lower respiratory tract infections since childhood; increased nasal epithelial ciliary beat frequency; Ciliary beat pattern was stiff, with a reduced bending amplitude; Axonemal cross-sections of the sperm flagella demonstrated disorganization of the microtubules.

evidence.dc:description: This variant will be scored for PMID: 36856967. This variant has been reported in five different probands, although it has not yet been identified as a founder mutation (PMIDs: 34089056, 36856967, 23354437, 34851034).
NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.352C>T (p.Gln118Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 84% truncated protein.
This variant was already scored for Case1
NC_000002.12:g.26398040_26425787del is a large 27,748 bp deletion spanning exons 1-4.

This variant will be scored for PMID: 36856967. This variant has been reported in five different probands, although it has not yet been identified as a founder mutation (PMIDs: 34089056, 36856967, 23354437, 34851034).

NM_145038.5(DRC1):c.352C>T (p.Gln118Ter) is a nonsense mutation predicted to trigger nonsense mediated decay or produce a 84% truncated protein. Normal 9+2 ciliary microtubule organization with absent N-DRC links in OP-59 II-2 respiratory cells (TEM).  IF studies of respiratory cells show absence of LRRC48 (DRC3 marker for N-DRC).
Down-scored by 0.5 for homozygosity
NC_000002.12:g.26398040_26425787del is a large 27,748 bp deletion spanning exons 1-4.

evidence.rdfs:label: Morimoto Case 1
evidence.detectionMethod: EM data suggested normal ciliary ultrastructure. Focused on sequencing PCD‐causative genes that do not affect ciliary ultrastructure (DNAH11, DRC1, CCDC65, GAS8, and HYDIN), which ultimately revealed that no reads mapped to exons 1 to 4 of DRC1 suggesting the presence of a homozygous deletion encompassing these exons.  The genomic region encompassing the deletion was amplified by PCR and direct Sanger sequencing showed a a 27,748 bp deletion. Authors subsequently excluded other genetic causes of PCD (DNAH5, DNAI1, CCDC39, CCDC40, C21orf59, DNAAF1, DNAAF2, DNAAF3, DNAAF4, DNAAF5, LRRC6, SPAG1, ZMYND10, CCNO, RSPH1, RSPH3, RSPH9, RSPH4A, ARMC4, CCDC103, CCDC151, DNAI2, DNAL1, NME8, CCDC114, PIH1D3, DNAJB13, TTC25).
